info.title: REST API for zbMATH Open
info.description:
This API provides cacheable and straightforward access to 
            zbMATH Open content and data, in machine-readable formats.

            
### Global Rules
            
- Each API endpoint's documentation may detail more specific 
            usage limits.
            
- By using this API, you agree to zbMATH's 
            [Terms and Conditions](
            https://api.zbmath.org/static/terms-and-conditions.html). 
            Unless otherwise specified in the endpoint documentation below, 
            content accessed via this API is licensed under the 
            [CC-BY-SA 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) 
            license, and  you irrevocably agree to release modifications or 
            additions made through this API under these licenses. 
            
 ### Legal restrictions and copyright
            
 The zbMATH Open OAI-PMH API is subject to the Terms and 
            Conditions for the zbMATH Open API Service of FIZ Karlsruhe – 
            Leibniz-Institut für Informationsinfrastruktur GmbH.
            
Content generated by zbMATH Open, such as reviews, 
            classifications, software, or author disambiguation data, 
            are distributed under CC-BY-SA 4.0. This defines the license for 
            the whole dataset, which also contains non-copyrighted 
            bibliographic metadata and reference data derived from I4OC (
            CC0). Note that the API only provides a subset of the data in the zbMATH Open Web interface. In several cases, third-party information, such as abstracts, cannot be made available under a suitable license through the API. In those cases, we replaced the data with the string
            
 "zbMATH Open Web Interface contents unavailable due to 
            conflicting licenses."
            
### Endpoint documentation
Please consult each 
            endpoint's documentation for details on:
            
- Licensing information for the specific type of content
            and data served via the endpoint.
            
- Endpoint specific usage limits.

            

            
[Terms and Conditions](https://api.zbmath.org/static/terms-and-conditions.html)

get.summary: introduction for user help regarding this endpoint
get.description:
# About this Endpoint 

For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search, which allows for convenient search of all relevant fields. 
The syntax search on the other hand allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields and is much more flexible. In the following you will find a short explanation of available search fields. 
Use the Authors Search to find information on specific authors. Author profiles include indexed publications, co-authors, main fields, and a citation profile. 
- **/_search**: make use of the zbMATH search syntax for complex search. Examples on how to make use of the syntax can be found  in the endpoint itself. 
- **/_structured_search**: a number of fields for a structured search 
- **/{id}**: if a zbMATH id for the author in question is available, you man enter it here, to return the meta data information of just this one author.

get.summary: search authors by zbMATH style user query
get.description: # Description The syntax search allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields. While similar to the structured search, this endpoint offers much more flexibility at the cost of obscure search parameters. # Examples - **(en:MGP | wikidata) ln:a***: Search results include all authors having either an entry in the Math Genealogy Project or in Wikidata and whose family name starts with A. - **(st:r & b) | (st:o)**: Search results include all reviewers with biographic information or collectives. - **Simon Donald***: Search in all parts of an author's name (results contain Simon, Donald M. and Donaldson, Simon Kirwan). - **au: Helga Bunke**: Search results include name variations, in particular name changes, different transliterations and pseudonyms. Names of collectives will be displayed as a separate entity. - **au: Stefan Müller cc:49**: Combine name search (au) with main MSC fields (cc). - **aw: Fields Abel**: Search for all Fields Medal award winners who also received an Abel Prize. The & operator is default and ommitted here. - **ln: Donald* fn: Simon**: Search for specified family (ln) and given (fn) name. # Search fields - **ai**: zbMATH code of author - **au**: Name of the Author - **aw**: Name of an Award (to find laureates) - **cc**: Main Fields of the Author (given by first two MSC digits) - **cm**: enter name of collective, result is authors in this collective - **co**: enter name of author, result is names of collectives the author is in - **en**: External Author ID: ORCID, MGP, Wikidata Numbers and others - **fn**: first Name of the Author - **ln**: last Name of the Author - **rv**: zbMATH reviewer ID - **sp**: alternative spelling variants of the author - **st**: Status of author: biographic reference (st:b), is cited (st:c), is collective (st:o), has reference (st:r). # Operators - **!ab**: logical not - **(ab c)**: parentheses - **a & b**: logical and - **a | b**: logical or - **ab c**: phrase - **abc***: right wildcard

get.summary: search authors by descriptive field names
get.description: # Description For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search for convenient combination of all search fields. While similar to the 1-line syntax search, this endpoint offers much more convenience and transparency which fields are searched at the cost of search flexibility. # Examples - **author_code: 'smith.ivan'**: Search for the author with the zbMATH code **smith.ivan** - **author_name: 'Smith'**: Search for authors with the name **Smith** - **collective: 'bass.hyman'**: Search for the names of the author collective(s) that the author with the zbMATH code **bass.hyman** is in. - **in_collective: 'bourbaki.nicolas'**: Search for authors that are in the author collective with the zbMATH code **bourbaki.nicolas** # Search fields - **author code**: zbMATH code of author - **author name**: Name of the Author - **award**: Name of an Award (to find laureates) - **collectives of**: enter name of collective, result is authors in this collective - **external id type**: External Author ID: ORCID, MGP, Wikidata Numbers and others - **first name**: first Name of the Author - **in collective**: enter name of author, result is names of collectives the author is in - **last name**: last Name of the Author - **main field**: Main Fields of the Author (given by first two MSC digits) - **reviewer**: zbMATH reviewer ID - **spelling**: alternative spelling variants of the author - **state**: Status of author: biographic reference (st:b), is cited (st:c), is collective (st:o), has reference (st:r).

get.summary: get author data by author code
get.description:
# About this zbMATH Identifier 



Use this endpoint if you have the exact zbMATH code of the author in question. The result will contain only one dataset corresponding to that code, if entered correctly.
The format of the author's zbMATH code is **lastname.firstname-additionalname**.
# Example
- **bourbaki.nicolas** is a collective of authors

get.summary: introduction for user help regarding this endpoint
get.description:
# About this Endpoint 

For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search, which allows for convenient search of all relevant fields. 
The syntax search on the other hand allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields and is much more flexible. In the following you will find a short explanation of available search fields. 
Use the Classification Search to find information on msc codes of research fields of interest. msc2020 codes available only.

**Level 0:** first two digits of msc code
**Level 1:** first two digits plus letter of msc code
**Level 2:** full msc code


- **/_search**: make use of the zbmath search syntax for complex search. Examples on how to make use of the syntax can be found in the endpoint itself.
- **/_structured_search**: a number of fields for a structured search
- **/{msc_code}**: if an identifier for the msc2020 code in question is available, you man enter it here, to return the meta data information of just this one msc2020 code.

get.summary: search msc codes meta data by zbMATH style user query
get.description: # Description The syntax search allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields. While similar to the structured search, this endpoint offers much more flexibility at the cost of obscure search parameters. # Examples - **Geometry**: Search for the term Geometry in any field. Queries are case - independent. # Search fields - **cc**: msc code (2020) - **ct**: descriptive title of msc code - **lv**: level of msc code resolution: first two digits of msc code (lv:0), first two digits plus letter of msc code (lv:1), full msc code (lv:2) - **pa**: parent level of msc code # Operators - **!ab**: logical not - **(ab c)**: parentheses - **a & b**: logical and - **a | b**: logical or - **ab c**: phrase - **abc***: right wildcard

get.summary: search msc codes meta data by descriptive field names
get.description: # Description For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search for convenient combination of all search fields. While similar to the 1-line syntax search, this endpoint offers much more convenience and transparency which fields are searched at the cost of search flexibility. # Examples - **code: '16'**: Search for all msc codes start with **16**. - **code: '16E20'**: Search for the exact msc code **16E20** - **title: 'dynamic'**: Search for all msc codes containing the descriptor **dynamic** # Search fields - **code**: msc code (2020) - **level**: level of msc code resolution: first two digits of msc code (lv:0), first two digits plus letter of msc code (lv:1), full msc code (lv:2) - **parent**: parent level of msc code - **title**: descriptive title of msc code

parameters.description: result page

get.summary: get msc2020 code data by code
get.description:
# About this zbMATH Identifier 



Use this endpoint if you have an exact msc2020 classification code in mind. The result will contain only one dataset corresponding to that code, if entered correctly.
# Example
- **20J05** leads to information about **'Homological methods in group theory'**

get.summary: introduction for user help regarding this endpoint
get.description:
# About this Endpoint 

For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search, which allows for convenient search of all relevant fields. \
The syntax search on the other hand allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields and is much more flexible. In the following you will find a short explanation of available search fields.\
Use the Documents Search to find documents on specific topics, by title or other characteristics. To find all publications by a specific author or from a specific journal you should instead use the respective search tab.

- **/_search**: make use of the zbmath search syntax for complex search. Examples on how to make use of the syntax can be found in the endpoint itself.
- **/_structured_search**: a number of fields for a structured search 
- **/{id}**: if a zbMATH id for the document in question is available, you man enter it here, to return the meta data information of just this one author.

get.summary: search documents by zbMATH style user query
get.description: # Description The syntax search allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields. While similar to the structured search, this endpoint offers much more flexibility at the cost of obscure search parameters. # Examples - **''Partial diff* eq*'' !elliptic**: The not -operator ! eliminates all results containing the word elliptic. - **Chebyshev | Tschebyscheff**: The or-operator | allows to search for Chebyshev or Tschebyscheff. - **Funct***: Wildcard queries are specified by * (e.g. functions, functorial, etc.). Otherwise the search is exact. - **Geometry**: Search for the term Geometry in any field. Queries are case-independent. - **Quasi* map* py: 1989**: The resulting documents have publication year 1989. - **Topological group**: Phrases(multi - words) should be set in straight quotation marks. - **au: Bourbaki & ti: Algebra**: Search for author Bourbaki and title Algebra. The and -operator & is default and can be omitted. - **dt: b & au: Hilbert**: The document type is set to books; alternatively: j for journal articles, a for book articles. - **la: chinese**: Find documents in a given language. ISO 639 - 1 (opens in new tab) language codes can also be used. - **py: 2000 - 2015 cc:(94A | 11T)**: Number ranges when searching for publication year are accepted. Terms can be grouped within (parentheses). - **so:Eur* J* Mat* Soc* cc:14**: Search for publications in a particular source with a Mathematics Subject Classification code in 14. - **st: c r s**: Find documents that are cited, have references and are from a single author. # Search fields - **ab**: Text from the Summary or Review of the Document - **ac**: zbMATH code of a uniquely identified contributor of a document - **ai**: zbMATH code of any contributor of a document - **an**: zbMATH ID of document, i.e.: pre ID, Zbl ID, JFM ID, ERAM ID - **ar**: zbMATH code of an author reference - **au**: Name(s) of the Contributor(s) of the document - **bi**: zbMATH code of the biographic reference - **br**: Name of a person with Biographic References (to find documents about the life or work) - **ca**: zbMATH code of a uniquely identified author of a document - **cc**: Code from the Mathematics Subject Classification MSC2020 (prefix with * to search only primary MSC) - **cca**: msc code (any level) - **ci**: zbMATH identifier(e.g. DE, Zbl) of citations in Zbl abstracts/reviews of a document - **db**: Database: Documents from Zentralblatt für Mathematik (db:Zbl) or Jahrbuch über die Fortschritte der Mathematik (db:JFM) - **dt**: Type of the Document: Journal Article (dt:j), Collection Article (dt:a), Book (dt:b) - **ec**: zbMATH code of a uniquely identified editor of a document - **ed**: Name of the Editor of a Book or Special Issue - **ei**: zbMATH code of editor of a document - **en**: External ID of a document: DOI, ISBN, arXiv ID and others - **ia**: zbMATH author code - **in**: zbMATH id of the corresponding issue - **la**: Language of the Document (use name, e.g., la:French, or ISO 639 - 1, e.g., la:FR) - **li**: External Link (URL) to the Document - **na**: number of authors of the document in question - **pt**: Reviewing State: Reviewed (pt:r), Title Only (pt:t), Pending (pt:p), Scanned Review (pt:s) - **pu**: Name of the Publisher of the Document - **py**: Year of Publication of the Document (enter year, e.g., py:2018, or year range, e.g. py:1990-2000) - **ra**: zbMATH code of author in reference - **rc**: MSC code of reference - **rf**: zbMATH ID of reference - **rft**: Text from the Reference List of the Document - **rj**: zbMATH ID of serial - **rn**: zbMATH code of reviewer - **rv**: Name or ID of the zbMATH Reviewer - **ry**: Publishing year of reference(s) - **se**: zbMATH ID of serial - **si**: zbMATH ID of related software - **so**: Source of the Document: Name of the Journal, Volume/Issue Number, Page Range, Year of Publication - **st**: State of document: Is cited (st:c), item has reference (st:r), item with single author (st:s) - **sw**: Name of Software used in the Document - **ti**: Title of the Document - **ut**: Keywords for the Document # Operators - **!ab**: logical not - **(ab c)**: parentheses - **a & b**: logical and - **a | b**: logical or - **ab c**: phrase - **abc***: right wildcard

get.summary: search documents by descriptive field names
get.description: # Description For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search for convenient combination of all search fields. While similar to the 1-line syntax search, this endpoint offers much more convenience and transparency which fields are searched at the cost of search flexibility. # Examples - **contributor_name: 'smith'**: Search for author, author reference or editor named **Smith** - **reference_author_code: 'ghezelahmad.somayeh-khalashi'**: Search for documents with references that were written by the author with the zbMATH code **smith.ivan** - **reference_zbmath_id: '6383667'**: Search for documents that reference to a document with the zbMATH id **6383667** - **year: '2002-2005'**: Search for documents published in the years from **2002** until **2005** - **zbmath_id: '6383667'**: Search for the document with the zbMATH id **6383667**. zbMATH id includes all types of identifiers used on zbmath.org, i.e.: pre ID, Zbl ID, JFM ID, ERAM ID # Search fields - **author code**: zbMATH author code - **author count**: number of authors of the document in question - **author reference code**: zbMATH code of an author reference - **biographic reference code**: zbMATH code of the biographic reference - **biographic reference name**: Name of a person with Biographic References (to find documents about the life or work) - **citing**: zbMATH identifier(e.g. DE, Zbl) of citations in Zbl abstracts/reviews of a document - **contributor code**: zbMATH code of any contributor of a document - **contributor name**: Name(s) of the Contributor(s) of the document - **database**: Database: Documents from Zentralblatt für Mathematik (db:Zbl) or Jahrbuch über die Fortschritte der Mathematik (db:JFM) - **document type**: Type of the Document: Journal Article (dt:j), Collection Article (dt:a), Book (dt:b) - **editor code**: zbMATH code of editor of a document - **editor name**: Name of the Editor of a Book or Special Issue - **external id**: External ID of a document: DOI, ISBN, arXiv ID and others - **issue id**: zbMATH id of the corresponding issue - **keyword**: Keywords for the Document - **language**: Language of the Document (use name, e.g., la:French, or ISO 639 - 1, e.g., la:FR) - **msc code**: msc code (any level) - **msc title**: Code from the Mathematics Subject Classification MSC2020 (prefix with * to search only primary MSC) - **publisher**: Name of the Publisher of the Document - **reference author_code**: zbMATH code of author in reference - **reference msc**: MSC code of reference - **reference series id**: zbMATH ID of serial - **reference text**: Text from the Reference List of the Document - **reference year**: Publishing year of reference(s) - **reference zbmath id**: zbMATH ID of reference - **related url**: External Link (URL) to the Document - **review text**: Text from the Summary or Review of the Document - **reviewer code**: zbMATH code of reviewer - **reviewer name**: Name or ID of the zbMATH Reviewer - **reviewing state**: Reviewing State: Reviewed (pt:r), Title Only (pt:t), Pending (pt:p), Scanned Review (pt:s) - **series id**: zbMATH ID of serial - **software id**: zbMATH ID of related software - **software name**: Name of Software used in the Document - **source**: Source of the Document: Name of the Journal, Volume/Issue Number, Page Range, Year of Publication - **state**: State of document: Is cited (st:c), item has reference (st:r), item with single author (st:s) - **title**: Title of the Document - **unique author code**: zbMATH code of a uniquely identified author of a document - **unique contributor code**: zbMATH code of a uniquely identified contributor of a document - **unique editor code**: zbMATH code of a uniquely identified editor of a document - **year**: Year of Publication of the Document (enter year, e.g., py:2018, or year range, e.g. py:1990-2000) - **zbmath id**: zbMATH ID of document, i.e.: pre ID, Zbl ID, JFM ID, ERAM ID

get.summary: get document data by zbMath ID
get.description:
# About this zbMATH Identifier 



Use this endpoint if you have an zbMATH id of the document in question. The result will contain only one dataset corresponding to that id, if entered correctly.
# Example
- **6383667**

get.summary: introduction for user help regarding this endpoint serial
get.description:
# About this Endpoint 
 
 For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search, which allows for convenient search of all relevant fields.
 The syntax search on the other hand allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields and is much more flexible. In the following you will find a short explanation of available search fields.
 Use the Serials Search to find information on journals or book serial. Serial profiles include indexed publications, volume lists, frequent authors and subjects, open access status, and citation profile.

- **/_search**: make use of the zbMATH search syntax for complex search. Examples on how to make use of the syntax can be found in the endpoint itself. 
- **/_structured_search**: a number of fields for a structured search
- **/{id}**: if a zbMATH id for the software in question is available, you man enter it here, to return the meta data information of just this one serial entry.

get.summary: search serial meta data by zbMATH style user query
get.description: # Description The syntax search allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields. While similar to the structured search, this endpoint offers much more flexibility at the cost of obscure search parameters. # Examples - **Ann* Math***: Search for the expressions in all fields. Abbreviations are also possible. - **jt:''Annals of Mathematics''**: Search for the exact journal title phrase. - **jt:Annals (cy: cn | ro)**: Search for journal title and country published in (here either China or Romania in two-digit ISO 3166-1 standard codes). - **jt:Annals cc: 05**: Search for journal title containing the sequence Annals and classification code of its main field (first two digits of MSC code). - **jt:annals pu: mathematics**: Search for journal title containing the sequence annals and publisher containing the sequencemathematics. - **py:1800 - 1899 la:no**: Search for 19th century serials which published in Norwegian. - **se:00002531**: Search for the exact serial identifier. This excludes homonyms. Compare to jt:Annals of Mathematics. - **sn:0003 - 486X**: Search for ISSN. Both electronic and print ISSN are accepted. - **tp:b**: Search for serials of the type book only - **tp:c r e**: Search for serials that are cited, have references and are only available electronically . - **tp:j st:o v t**: Search for serials of the type journal which are in the state open access and currently indexed cover-to-cover and are validated. # Search fields - **cc**: Main Fields of the Serial (given by first two MSC digits) - **cy**: Country of the Publisher: use name (e.g. cy:France) or ISO 3166-1 codes (e.g. cy:FR) - **jt**: Title of the Serial (including acronyms and shorttitles) - **la**: Languages of Indexed Documents (la:French, or ISO 639 - 1 codes, e.g., la:FR) - **li**: External Link (URL) to the Serial - **pu**: Name of the Publisher - **py**: Time Period the Serial was active (py:2018, or year range py:1990-2000) - **sn**: International Standard Serial Number (ISSN) - **st**: Publishing State: Open Access (st:o), Electronic Only (st:e), Indexed (st:v), Cover to Cover (st:t) - **tp**: Type of the Serial: Journal (tp:j), Book Series (tp:b) # Operators - **!ab**: logical not - **(ab c)**: parentheses - **a & b**: logical and - **a | b**: logical or - **ab c**: phrase - **abc***: right wildcard

get.summary: search serial meta data by descriptive field names
get.description: # Description For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search for convenient combination of all search fields. While similar to the 1-line syntax search, this endpoint offers much more convenience and transparency which fields are searched at the cost of search flexibility. # Examples - **title: 'Annals of Mathematics'**: Search for journal title phrase - **year: '1800-1899'**: Search for 19th century serials # Search fields - **country**: Country of the Publisher: use name (e.g. cy:France) or ISO 3166-1 codes (e.g. cy:FR) - **issn**: International Standard Serial Number (ISSN) - **language**: Languages of Indexed Documents (la:French, or ISO 639 - 1 codes, e.g., la:FR) - **main field**: Main Fields of the Serial (given by first two MSC digits) - **publisher**: Name of the Publisher - **serial type**: Type of the Serial: Journal (tp:j), Book Series (tp:b) - **state**: Publishing State: Open Access (st:o), Electronic Only (st:e), Indexed (st:v), Cover to Cover (st:t) - **title**: Title of the Serial (including acronyms and shorttitles) - **url**: External Link (URL) to the Serial - **year**: Time Period the Serial was active (py:2018, or year range py:1990-2000)

get.summary: get serial data by serial id
get.description:
# About this zbMATH Identifier 



Use this endpoint if you have the exact zbMATH id of the serial in question. The result will contain only one dataset corresponding to that id, if entered correctly.
# Example
- **3191**: leads to information about serial **'Advances inDifference Equations'**

get.summary: introduction for user help regarding this endpoint software
get.description:
# About this Endpoint 

For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search, which allows for convenient search of all relevant fields. 
The syntax search on the other hand allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields and is much more flexible. In the following you will find a short explanation of available search fields.
Use the Software Search to find information on specific software and where it is used.

- **/_search**: make use of the zbMATH search syntax for complex search. Examples on how to make use of the syntax can be found in the endpoint itself.
- **/_structured_search**: a number of fields for a structured search
- **/{id}**: if a zbMATH id for the software in question is available, you man enter it here, to return the meta data information of just this one software entry.

get.summary: search software meta data by zbMATH style user query
get.description: # Description The syntax search allows for free logical combinations of all available search fields. While similar to the structured search, this endpoint offers much more flexibility at the cost of obscure search parameters. # Examples - **GAP au:Eick**: Search for GAP in the any index (which also includes dependencies) and by software author containing the sequence Eick. - **ab:geometry & ut:ORMS**: Search for software packages with the word geometry in the description(ab), and which have the keyword(ut) ORMS ( Oberwolfach Registry of Mathematical Software).The operator & is the default and may be omitted. - **cc:13 | 14**: Search for software packages which are cited(cc) by articles belonging to the classification code sections 13 and 14. - **pl:Java & ab:R**: Search for software package in the programming language Java whose description text(ab) contains R - **sw:Sage***: Search for a specific software package containing the sequence Sage. # Search fields - **ab**: Text from the Software Description - **au**: Name(s) of the Author(s) of the Software - **cc**: Main Fields of the Software (given by first two MSC digits) - **pl**: Programming Language the Software is written in - **sw**: Name of the Software - **ut**: Keywords for the Software # Operators - **!ab**: logical not - **(ab c)**: parentheses - **a & b**: logical and - **a | b**: logical or - **ab c**: phrase - **abc***: right wildcard

get.summary: search software meta data by descriptive field names
get.description:
# Description

 
 
 For searching in zbMATH you may employ the Structured Search for convenient combination of all search fields. While similar to the 1-line syntax search, this endpoint offers much more convenience and transparency which fields are searched at the cost of search flexibility.
 # Examples 

 
 - **author: 'smith'**: Search for author named **Smith**
- **keyword': 'dynamic'**: Search for keyword **dynamic** associated with the software
- **programming_language: 'python'**: Search for software based on the programming language **python**

# Search fields

 
 - **author**: Name(s) of the Author(s) of the Software
- **description**: Text from the Software Description
- **keyword**: Keywords for the Software
- **msc**: Main Fields of the Software (given by first two MSC digits)
- **name**: Name of the Software
- **programming language**: Programming Language the Software is written in

editorial_contributions.text:
The prime \(k\)-tuples and small gaps between prime numbers are considered. Using a refinement of the Goldston-Pintz-Yildirim sieve method [\textit{D. A. Goldston} et al., Ann. Math. (2) 170, No. 2, 819--862 (2009; Zbl 1207.11096)] the author proves, for instance, the following estimates 
\[
 \liminf_{n\to\infty}\,(p_{n+m}-p_n)\ll m^3\text{{e}}^{4m}, \quad \liminf_{n\to\infty}\,(p_{n+1}-p_n)\leq 600
\]
 with an absolute constant in sign \(\ll\). Here \(m\) is a natural number, and \(p_{\,l}\) denote the \(l\)-th prime number.

references.text: P. D. T. A. Elliott and H. Halberstam, ''A conjecture in prime number theory,'' in Symposia Mathematica, Vol. IV, London: Academic Press, 1970, pp. 59-72.

serial.publisher: Princeton University, Mathematics Department, Princeton, NJ
serial.title: Annals of Mathematics. Second Serial

example.name: zbMATH Open Web Interface contents unavailable due to conflicting licenses.

example.text:
The prime \(k\)-tuples and small gaps between prime numbers are considered. Using a refinement of the Goldston-Pintz-Yildirim sieve method [\textit{D. A. Goldston} et al., Ann. Math. (2) 170, No. 2, 819--862 (2009; Zbl 1207.11096)] the author proves, for instance, the following estimates 
\[
 \liminf_{n\to\infty}\,(p_{n+m}-p_n)\ll m^3\text{{e}}^{4m}, \quad \liminf_{n\to\infty}\,(p_{n+1}-p_n)\leq 600
\]
 with an absolute constant in sign \(\ll\). Here \(m\) is a natural number, and \(p_{\,l}\) denote the \(l\)-th prime number.
D. A. Goldston, J. Pintz, and C. Y. Yildirim, ''Primes in tuples. I,'' Ann. of Math., vol. 170, iss. 2, pp. 819-862, 2009.

comments:
Published electronic only as of 2004.
This journal is available open access.
example.title: Advances in Difference Equations

example.publisher: Springer US, New York, NY; Mathematica Josephina, St. Louis, MO
example.title: The Journal of Geometric Analysis

example.description: GAP is a system for computational discrete algebra, with particular emphasis on Computational Group Theory. GAP provides a programming language, a library of thousands of functions implementing algebraic algorithms written in the GAP language as well as large data libraries of algebraic objects. See also the overview and the description of the mathematical capabilities. GAP is used in research and teaching for studying groups and their representations, rings, vector spaces, algebras, combinatorial structures, and more. The system, including source, is distributed freely. You can study and easily modify or extend it for your special use. Computer algebra system (CAS).
example.name: GAP
example.operating_systems: Linux, Unix, Mac OS X, Windows
